comment.author: 66853325@N00
comment._content: It's great that stuff like William Hope's is now available to see via the Commons. This particular image is perhaps even more startling as a square thumbnail - the collar and tie on the left look like goofy teeth belonging to a large deformed head. What's particularly intriguing with Hope's "ghosts" is that Arthur Conan Doyle said the photographs were "fakes", but he thought the Cottingley Fairies were real! -- Seen on my Flickr home page. (?)

comment.author: 23014017@N03
comment._content: The photo looks to have been processed in a darkroom due to the finger print on the right hand side of the photo. So no photoshop was used here. However the use of burning and dodging would also give desired results. Along with the use of sandwiching negatives and using a longer developing times. The sad fact is how many of these are real? Compared to the many that are fakes. You would need the original negative to even begin making a decision.

comment.author: 28611924@N03
comment._content: An excellent example of the spirit photography held in such high regard by Victorian Spiritualists. But yes, it's probably faked! The ectoplasm (the spirit substance which issued from the medium's mouth) was no doubt added via double exposure or a similar method. But, as a modern day Spiritualist, I believe it was done with all good intentions to illustrate the continuity of existence after death.
